summary: The declassified intelligence report provides insights into the Cuban Revolution, focusing on key figures such as Ernesto 'Che' Guevara and Fidel Castro. It details Guevara's strategic movements with a group of men near Manacas in West Las Villas to disrupt central highway traffic west of Santa Clara. The document also highlights the 26th of July Movement's actions, including the replacement of CTC officials with their own members on captured sugar centrals, and mentions a small FEU force active near Coliseo in Matanzas. Additionally, it reports on an arms shipment seized in Cayo Hueso, Florida, intended for Havana, and Batista's engagement of French Army officers with guerrilla warfare expertise to advise the Cuban Army.
key_findings: Ernesto Guevara's strategic movement westward with 165 men near Manacas in West Las Villas aimed at cutting off central highway traffic west of Santa Clara.
The 26th of July Movement replaced CTC officials with their own members on captured sugar centrals.
A small FEU force was active near Coliseo in Matanzas, and an arms shipment seized in Cayo Hueso, Florida, was intended for use in Havana.
Batista contracted French Army officers experienced in guerrilla warfare to advise the Cuban Army.
